{{Other uses|Paddle (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} [[File:Paddle.jpg|thumb|400px|right|A spanking paddle]] A spanking '''paddle''' is an implement used to strike a person on the buttocks. The act of spanking a person with a paddle is known as "paddling". A paddling may be for punishment (normally of a student at school in the United States), or as an initiation or [[hazing]] ritual.
==Description== A paddle has two parts: a handle and a blade. Most paddles are designed to be held with one hand, but a giant paddle may be designed to be held with two hands.<ref>[https://www.flickr.com/photos/photognome/2708830973/in/photostream/ Image] of a very large spanking paddle that was designed to be held with two hands.</ref> The blade is typically 3 to {{convert|4|in|mm}} wide, 1/4-inch thick, and 1 to {{convert|3|ft|m}} in length.
In the great majority of cases, the paddle is aimed at the recipient's buttocks. Less commonly, the back of the thighs might also be targeted.<ref>"The act of punishment is to be conducted in such a manner that the area of contact will lie between and include the buttocks and the back of the thigh". [http://www.tipton-county.com/Student%20Handbook%202009.10.pdf ''Student Handbook'']{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (2009), p. 19. Tipton County Schools, Tennessee.</ref>
Paddles for use in schools are made of wood, or occasionally plastic.<ref>"Corporal punishment shall be administered using an instrument (paddle) made of wood or plastic of reasonable width, length, and thickness. (The paddle shall not be more than 1/4" x 3" x 18".)" [http://www.tasb.org/policy/pol/private/212905/pol.cfm?DisplayPage=FO(LOCAL).pdf&QueryText=PADDLE ''Policy On Line: Student Discipline'']{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, p. 2. Tyler independent school District, Texas.</ref> Paddles used for school punishments may be roughly hewn from commonly available wood.<ref>[https://www.flickr.com/photos/wfryer/1014497362/sizes/o/ Image] of a roughly hewn schoolhouse paddle.</ref> Occasionally, paddles may have holes drilled into them, so there is less air drag when the paddle approaches the buttocks, and produces more sting. The paddles used for fraternity and sorority initiation ceremonies are often professionally made and engraved with organizational symbols and slogans.<ref>[http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:SororityPaddlingFinalexam280.jpg Image] of a decorated sorority paddle from a fictional spanking film.</ref>
==History of the paddle== [[File:Spanking paddle invented to beat slaves.jpg|thumb|250px|Illustration of a paddle being used for the punishment of slaves.]] The paddle may have been originally invented for the punishment of slaves as a way of causing intense pain without doing any permanent damage to the recipient.<ref>Scott, George Ryley (1938). [https://books.google.com/books?id=5NbaAAAAMAAJ&dq=The+History+of+Corporal+Punishment&q=punctured#search_anchor ''The history of corporal punishment: a survey of flagellation in its historical, anthropological, and sociological aspects''], 2nd Edition, T. W. Laurie, London.</ref> It is not only in former slave states that the paddle has been used in schools. It is not known why or exactly when it became the normal implement for corporal punishment in US schools. There are however instances of paddling using similar implements with individuals who were not slaves.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}}
==Scope of use== {{Corporal punishment}} [[File:Punishment of the Paddle, 1912.jpg|thumb|250px|1912 illustration of an inmate being punished in an American prison]] Paddling was mainly used in many parts of the United States (and still is, in a few areas) as a means to discipline misbehaving school students. Paddling has also been used in some homes to punish children.<ref>[http://www.wlwt.com/news/22591959/detail.html ''Dad Found Not Guilty In Paddling Case.''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225075355/http://www.wlwt.com/news/22591959/detail.html |date=25 February 2012 }} [[WLWT]], ''News 5,'' Cincinnati, Ohio. 17 February 2010.</ref><ref>In 2005, a father in Minnesota used a paddle to strike his son 36 times. [http://www.lawlibrary.state.mn.us/archive/supct/0805/OPA070152-0530.pdf Minnesota Supreme Court]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, 30 May 2008.</ref> The results of a national household survey indicate that paddling is a discipline technique that 10% of parents are "very likely to use". The percentage of parents who say that they are very likely to paddle increases to 12% when involving teenagers.<ref>C.S. Mott Children's Hospital (2010). [http://www.med.umich.edu/mott/npch/pdf/041510report.pdf "Speak or Spank? More Parents Choose Reasoning Than Physical Discipline".] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607100243/http://www.med.umich.edu/mott/npch/pdf/041510report.pdf |date=7 June 2010 }} ''National Poll on Children's Health,'' Vol. 9, Issue 4, 16 April 2010.</ref>
===Paddling as punishment in U.S. schools=== {{main|School corporal punishment}} The paddle is the almost invariable implement in US schools that still allow corporal punishment for student misconduct. Some paddles have traditionally had holes bored in them for aerodynamic effect,<ref>[[Human Rights Watch]] (2008). [https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/us0808webwcover.pdf ''A Violent Education: Corporal Punishment of Children in US Public Schools,''] p. 17.</ref> but many schools nowadays prohibit the use of such paddles.<ref>"A paddle made of wood with no holes or splinters shall be used in administering corporal punishment..." Rapides Parish School Board (2005). [http://www.rapides.k12.la.us/policy/student/SECTION_I.pdf ''Parish Policy Handbook and Student Code of Conduct.'']{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>"The punishment shall consist of no more than three swats on the buttocks with a smooth surface paddle free of holes and/or cracks." Calhoun County Schools. [http://www.calhoun.k12.al.us/parent/Doc/HANDBOOK06-07.doc ''2006–2007 Student Handbook and Code of Student Conduct.''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606213440/http://www.calhoun.k12.al.us/parent/Doc/HANDBOOK06-07.doc |date=6 June 2011 }}</ref>
Paddling typically causes a slight reddening of the skin but in some cases can cause [[bruise]]s that are "visible for approximately two weeks".<ref>Harrison, Mark. [http://times-journal.com/news/article_43a9c106-b315-11e0-b2ae-001cc4c002e0.html "Lawsuit filed over paddling incident"]. ''[[Times-Journal]],'' [[DeKalb County, Alabama]], 20 July 2011.</ref> Whether or not particular bruises constitute evidence of "serious injury" or "abuse"<ref>[http://www.aoc.state.nc.us/www/public/coa/opinions/2006/pdf/051517-1.pdf In re: C.B., J.B., Th.B., & Ti.B.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610170404/http://www.aoc.state.nc.us/www/public/coa/opinions/2006/pdf/051517-1.pdf |date=10 June 2011 }}, North Carolina Court of Appeals, 15 August 2006.</ref> or "child maltreatment"<ref>[http://www.lexisone.com/lx1/caselaw/freecaselaw?action=OCLGetCaseDetail&format=FULL&sourceID=beehcb&searchTerm=eNeE.GUda.UWTb.LcQC&searchFlag=y&l1loc=FCLOW Arkansas Department of Human Services v. Shelly Holman] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716093932/http://www.lexisone.com/lx1/caselaw/freecaselaw?action=OCLGetCaseDetail&format=FULL&sourceID=beehcb&searchTerm=eNeE.GUda.UWTb.LcQC&searchFlag=y&l1loc=FCLOW |date=16 July 2011 }}, Arkansas Court of Appeals, 4 October 2006.</ref> depends on individual circumstances and can ultimately be settled only by a [[court of law]].
There have been cases in the past when paddling was administered incorrectly or excessively. Partly in order to avoid this danger, in the majority of U.S. schools, paddling is more strictly regulated than in the past, many schools publishing detailed rules in their student handbooks.<ref name="handbooks">[http://www.corpun.com/usscr2.htm Corporal punishment regulations of individual schools or school districts] (external links to present-day school handbooks) at World Corporal Punishment Research.</ref> It is usually a requirement that a professional witness be present. Currently, there is often a maximum of three swats (or "licks" or "pops"). In the past, paddlings of up to 30<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2g1QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=c1UDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5696,3515697&hl=en "Paddling Charge Dropped; School Bell Rings Again"]. ''[[Evening Independent]],'' 19 April 1960, p. 3-A.</ref> licks were not unknown, especially in rural schools.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} Practice has gradually moved from paddlings in the classroom or hallway to paddlings administered out of the sight of other students, typically in the principal's office. "Hallway" paddlings could typically be seen by other students, administrators or even outsiders visiting the school.
In 1981, a 17-year-old student claimed bleeding wounds as a result of a school paddling.<ref>[http://www.nospank.net/shelly.htm Testimony of Shelly S. Gaspersohn] at a meeting of the United States Senate's Subcommittee on Juvenile Justice, 17 October 1984.</ref> It was alleged that the assistant principal who had administered the punishment had held and swung the paddle with ''two'' hands.<ref>[http://nc.findacase.com/research/wfrmDocViewer.aspx/xq/fac.19850604_0041310.NC.htm/qx Gaspersohn v. Harnett County Board of Education and Glenn Varney]; North Carolina Court of Appeals, Volume 75, page 34 (1985).</ref> In order to prevent such claims, a school district currently may choose to require the handle of a spanking paddle to be "just large enough for a normal one-hand grip".<ref>Santa Rosa County School District (2009). [http://www.santarosa.k12.fl.us/files/csc.pdf ''Code of Student Conduct,''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100702115632/http://www.santarosa.k12.fl.us/files/csc.pdf |date=2 July 2010 }} p. 59.</ref> Or a rule might provide that the handle shall not be more than {{convert|4|in|mm}} long (just large enough to be held with one hand).<ref name="Alexander">Alexander City Schools (2010). [http://www.alex.k12.al.us/handbook/hand.pdf ''Student/Parent Information Guide and Code of Conduct, 2009–2010 School Year,''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090824024436/http://www.alex.k12.al.us/handbook/hand.pdf |date=24 August 2009 }} p. 47.</ref>
In 1982, a nine-year-old student was hit with a wooden paddle that was cracked.<ref>[http://openjurist.org/817/f2d/650 ''Garcia v. Miera.''] United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit, 28 April 1987.</ref> This caused a bleeding wound that became a permanent scar. To avoid this, nowadays some school districts have adopted rules which prohibit using paddles that have cracks in them. For example, the policies of Bloomfield School District provide that, "Corporal punishment will be administered by spanking the buttocks of a student with a flat-surfaced paddle which is smoothly sanded and has no cracks or holes and that will cause no more than temporary pain and not inflict permanent damage to the body."<ref>See the fifth paragraph of section J-4661 of the [http://www.bsin.k12.nm.us/policies/ ''Policy Manual and Administrative Regulations''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110304011607/http://www.bsin.k12.nm.us/policies/ |date=4 March 2011 }} of the Bloomfield School District, New Mexico.</ref>
A paddling is typically administered with two or more school employees present. The student may be ordered to bend over a chair<ref>"He [a school principal] told her [an 18-year-old student] to bend over a chair with her buttocks raised." Sacks, Deana Pollard (2009). [http://lawreview.law.ucdavis.edu/issues/42-4_Sacks.pdf "State Actors Beating Children: A Call For Judicial Relief".] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612221633/http://lawreview.law.ucdavis.edu/issues/42-4_Sacks.pdf |date=12 June 2010 }} ''University of California Davis Law Review,'' 42, p. 1167.</ref> or desk<ref>"The force of the blow caused Bria to lose her grip on the ''desk'' and fall against it". Hyman, Irwin A, and Snook, Pamela A (1999). [https://books.google.com/books?ei=yH4sTtSoJOLj0gHB88nkDg&ct=result&id=qwefAAAAMAAJ&dq=Dangerous+Schools%3A+What+We+Can+Do+About+the+Physical+and+Emotional+Abuse+of+Our+Children&q=desk#search_anchor ''Dangerous Schools: What We Can Do About the Physical and Emotional Abuse of Our Children''], p. 20. [[John Wiley & Sons|Jossey-Bass Publishers]], New York, NY; {{ISBN|0-7879-4363-0}}, {{ISBN|978-0-7879-4363-9}}.</ref> and, in that position, receive the prescribed number of strokes of the paddle. Paddling usually occurs in an office but may sometimes occur in a hallway. The punishment is delivered across the seat of the student's trousers or skirt.
In order to avoid allegations of sexual abuse, many school districts require that a female teacher be present during the paddling of a female student.<ref>The [http://www.burke.k12.nc.us/superintendent/boe/Policies/Section10/10.3610%20%20Corporal%20Punishment.pdf Burke County Public Schools paddling policy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100714123523/http://www.burke.k12.nc.us/superintendent/boe/Policies/Section10/10.3610%20%20Corporal%20Punishment.pdf |date=14 July 2010 }} provides that, "In the event of corporal punishment being administered to a female student, a female teacher shall at all times be present".</ref> A school might also ''recommend'' "that female staff members administer corporal punishment to female students (middle and high school)".<ref>St. Johns County School District (2010). [http://www.stjohns.k12.fl.us/rules/Conduct_Code_2010-2011.pdf Student Code of Conduct 2010–2011] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727051741/http://www.stjohns.k12.fl.us/rules/Conduct_Code_2010-2011.pdf |date=27 July 2011 }}, p. 34.</ref> Or a school board might ''prescribe'' that a "female principal(s) or designee shall spank or paddle female students" and that a "male principal(s) or designee shall spank or paddle male students."<ref>[http://www.cbs19.tv/Global/story.asp?S=10228878 ''Chapel Hill ISD Board Amends Corporal Punishment Policy.''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229233839/http://www.cbs19.tv/Global/story.asp?S=10228878 |date=29 February 2012 }} Television station [[KYTX]], 22 April 2009.</ref>
As of April 2011, 19 states allow corporal punishment in public schools. See [[School corporal punishment in the United States]] for further information.
===Social discipline=== *Some university or college traditions enforce(d) rules by paddling offenders. In the University of Missouri until World War II,<ref>[http://www.mizzou.com/traditions.htm 'Paddle Lines' at David R. Francis Quadrangle], "Mizzou Traditions" web page.</ref> any freshman found on the 'quad', the most prestigious square on campus, had to offer his 'insolent' posterior for punishment along a ''paddle line'' formed by swatting seniors. *[[Fraternities and sororities]] are commonly associated with paddling of members, especially new members or pledges, as part of their [[hazing]] rituals.<ref>Smith, Emily E. [http://www.theblaze.com/stories/animal-house-style-hazing-he-was-paddled-so-hard-he-needed-medical-treatment/ "Animal House-style Hazing: 'He was paddled so hard he needed medical treatment'"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110428123725/http://www.theblaze.com/stories/animal-house-style-hazing-he-was-paddled-so-hard-he-needed-medical-treatment/ |date=28 April 2011 }}. [[The Blaze (web site)|''The Blaze'']], 22 April 2011.</ref><ref>Sorority pledges are paddled during the movie ''[[Sorority Babes in the Slimeball Bowl-O-Rama]]'' (1988).</ref> Due to modern anti-hazing laws<ref name=laws>{{cite web | title = State Anti-Hazing Laws | work = StopHazing.org: Educating to Eliminate Hazing | url = http://www.stophazing.org/laws.html | accessdate = 27 July 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090422161349/http://www.stophazing.org/laws.html | archivedate = 22 April 2009 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> and regulations, this has declined. This subculture is peculiar to North America. {{Citation needed|reason=reliable source needed for the whole sentence|date=January 2013}}
===Other play and traditions=== [[File:BDSM couple with spanking paddle.jpg|thumb|Practitioners of [[erotic spanking]] using a paddle]] The paddle is also a favorite implement for non-disciplinary "fun" spankings such as "[[birthday spankings]]," as also for [[paddle game (spanking)|paddle game]]s (such as [[trading blows]]) or a spanking pyramid or [[paddle machine]]. A paddle machine can be used in conjunction with a [[spanking bench]]. Numerous celebrities, including [[Jessica Jaymes]], [[Jennifer Krum]], [[Haydn Porter]], [[Tabitha Stevens]] and [[Victoria Zdrok]], have mounted [[Howard Stern | Howard Stern's]] spanking bench to be paddled by his paddle machine, the "[[Robospanker]]".<ref>[http://viewmorepics.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=viewImage&friendID=123290354&albumID=833721&imageID=11182870 Image] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090911230433/http://viewmorepics.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=viewImage |date=11 September 2009 }} of [http://www.playboy.com/girls/coeds/cotw/haydn-porter/haydn-porter.html Haydn Porter] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100713185345/http://www.playboy.com/girls/coeds/cotw/haydn-porter/haydn-porter.html |date=13 July 2010 }} kneeling on a spanking bench and being paddled by a paddle machine during [http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1167886800 ''A Spanking New Year''], the 4 January 2007 episode of ''[[The Howard Stern Show]].''</ref> Paddles are also used by practitioners of [[erotic spanking]].
==See also== *[[Spanking]] *[[Corporal punishment]] *[[Caning]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category|Paddles (spanking)}} *[http://www.corpun.com/counuss.htm "Corporal punishment in US schools"] at World Corporal Punishment Research
[[Category:School punishments]] [[Category:Spanking implements]]

{{refimprove|date=January 2008}} {{globalize/US|date=April 2016}} {{Property law}} A '''partition''' is a term used in the [[law]] of [[real property]] to describe an act, by a [[court]] order or otherwise, to divide up a [[concurrent estate]] into separate portions representing the proportionate interests of the owners of property. It is sometimes described as a '''forced sale'''. Under the [[common law]], any owner of property who owns an undivided concurrent interest in land can seek such a division. In some cases, the parties agree to a specific division of the land; if they are unable to do so, the court will determine an appropriate division. A sole owner, or several owners, of a piece of land may partition their land by entering a [[deed poll]] (sometimes referred to as "carving out"). == Why forced sales occur == Forced sales generally occur because owners of property are unable to agree upon certain aspects of the ownership. The owners may disagree on how to use the property, on the amount of money to invest into the property, or on their right to occupy and use the whole of the property. If the parties cannot come to an agreement, the case moves to court through a petition to partition action.[http://www.andysirkin.com/HTMLArticle.cfm?Article=1 Tenancy in Common Questions and Answers - Andy Sirkin, Attorney] As the number of co-habitants increases in the United States, the petition to partition action has become more common as a remedy to divide real and personal property.[http://www.ricefamilylaw.com/family/petition-to-partition.htm] Property may be owned by more than one person either as [[joint tenants]], [[tenants in common]], and in some states [[tenants by the entirety]].[http://real-estate-law.freeadvice.com/real-estate-law/property_ownership_forms.htm Property ownership - what are the common forms?] The choice of which tenancy to enter into is made by the parties at the time of purchase. With each type of tenancy, each owner has the right to occupy the whole. That means that an owner is not allowed to designate certain rooms as their own and so on. Each element of the property is enjoyed fully by all parties. ==Types of partition== There are three kinds of partition which can be awarded by court: ''partition in kind'', ''partition by allotment'', and ''partition by sale''. #A partition in kind is a division of the property itself among the co-owners. Partition in kind is a default method of property partition.Partition Action 101. [http://www.partitionaction.com Partition Action] #In a partition by allotment, which is not available in all jurisdictions, the court awards full ownership of the land to a single owner or subset of owners, and orders them to pay the person or persons divested of ownership for the interest awarded. #Partition by sale constitutes a forced sale of the land, followed by division of the profits thus realized among the tenants. Generally, the court is supposed to order a partition sale only if the land cannot be physically divided, although this determination often rests on whether the economic value of the divided pieces is less in the aggregate than the value of the parcel as a single piece. ''See'' Delfino v. Vealencis, 436 A.2d 27 (Conn. 1980). A provision in a [[deed]] completely prohibiting partition will not be given effect, but courts will enforce a provision that temporarily restricts partition, as long as the restriction is reasonable. == Statutory variations == === Ontario, Canada Code === The Ontario Partition Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. P.4, states: :"3. (1) Any person interested in land in Ontario, or the guardian of a minor entitled to the immediate possession of an estate therein, may bring an action or make an application for the partition of such land or for the sale thereof under the directions of the court if such sale is considered by the court to be more advantageous to the parties interested. R.S.O. 1990, c. P.4, s. 3 (1)." ===Florida statutes=== Florida provides for partition actions by statute, Chapter 64, which basically provides that any co-owner of real estate may seek partition.[http://www.flsenate.gov/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&URL=Ch0064/ch0064.htm Florida Partition Statute] In Florida, there are basically no defenses to a partition action, other than if the parties have agreed not to partition the real estate.[http://www.floridaprobatetrustlaw.com/2009/12/articles/florida-homestead/partition-can-be-the-solution-for-florida-heirs/ Partition Can Be the Solution for Florida Heirs] ===Pennsylvania code===
* Property divided under Rule 1560(a) shall be awarded to the parties according to their respective interests. * A master who is appointed by the court shall make such examinations and hold such hearings as may be necessary, giving reasonable notice thereof. The master may employ appraisers and, with the authorization of the court, such other experts as are necessary to enable the master to perform his or her duties.The Pennsylvania Code * The court shall permit the shares of any two or more co-tenants to remain undivided between them if they so elect by writing filed within such time as the court or master shall direct. * Parties defendant owning a majority in value of the property may object in writing to any sale, requesting that the property be awarded to them at its valuation fixed by the court and that their interests in the same remain undivided. Upon such request the entire property shall be awarded to the parties objecting to sale, as tenants in common, subject to payment to the parties desiring partition and sale of the amounts of their respective interests based upon the valuation. The amounts due the parties shall be charged as liens upon the property, to be paid in such manner and time as the court shall direct.
;Partition example: In D’Arcy v. Buckley, 71 Bucks Co. L. Rep. 167 (1997), two people purchased property as joint tenants with right of survivorship. The plaintiff contributed five times more than the defendant toward the purchase price. In a partition action, the plaintiff sought credit for the full amount of his superior contributions. The Court held that, in the absence of fraud, the working of the deed operated to convey a one-half interest to each of the two joint tenants. The decision relies the authorities of Masgai v. Masgai, 460 Pa. 453, 333 A.2d 861 (1975), and DeLoatch v. Murphy, 369 Pa. Super. 255, 535 A.2d 146 (1987). The plaintiff argued, to no avail, that he did not intend to make a lifetime gift to defendant. === California Code === Partition in kind is favored, Cal. Civ. Proc. Code § 872.810,http://www.oclaw.org/research/code/ca/CCP/872.810./content.html but partition by sale is allowed if a partition by sale maximizes the market value of the subject property(s). In many cases, a two-step process may be required: (1) a trial,As partition actions are "equitable" in nature, only court trials are employed; i.e., jury trials are not permitted. during which oral and documentary evidence is heard, and either affirms or denies the right of the moving party to effect a partition of the subject property(s), and, if affirmed, results in an interlocutory judgment (sometimes called a "first interlocutory judgment"), and (2) particularly in a contested partition, an evidentiary hearing (also a trial), usually after the property(s) have been appraised by experts, and during which trial additional oral and documentary evidence is heard, the property(s) are ordered divided and awarded proportionally where possible, including cash compensation where proportional division is impractical or impossible (sometimes called a "second interlocutory judgment"). The division usually requires the employment of experts such as engineers and surveyors, and the preparation of special reports (which include conveyance deeds and easement deeds). As a final act, the court, in a hearing (not a trial), will accept the special reports and order that these be executed by a title company, which will also effectuate "recordation" of the conveyance and easement deeds (any cash compensation due any of the parties will also be effectuated within the escrow). ===Partition procedure=== A party seeking a partition must file a partition lawsuit. State codes generally favor physical division (partition in-kind) of the affected property(s) over sale (partition by sale as a unit), particularly if a tenant would be displaced from his or her primary residence by a sale. If in-kind partition is feasible, the property(s) will be divided proportionally. Where small differences in such division are unavoidable, cash compensation for the difference(s) will be awarded to maintain proportionality. If the property(s) cannot be divided and allocated to give each tenant a portion without spoiling the whole, the court will order a sale. A special master (referee) is commonly appointed by the court to execute the partition process. The referee is responsible only to the court, and the referee is limited only by the court's instructions, and applicable state codes. For an in-kind partition, the referee will cause deeds to the adjusted property(s) to be prepared. Where easements are required for access, the referee will employ professionals (engineers, surveyors and other experts) as required to describe the easement(s). The conveyance deeds for the adjusted property(s) and the easement deed(s) will be recorded simultaneously. Often, "referee's deeds" (deeds signed by the referee, in the owner's stead) may be employed. ===Tenants in common partitions vs. tenants with rights of survivorship partitions=== Tenants in common (TIC) deeds may or may not be taken in equal shares, but a joint tenants with rights of survivorship (JTWROS) deed must always be taken in equal shares unless specifically and clearly indicated otherwise in the deed language. Therefore, a partition action for those two types of deeds will vary. When a JTWROS property is partitioned, the proceeds must be divided equally among tenants without regard to contribution to purchase price since a JTWROS deed is always taken in equal shares. So with a JTWROS, contributions to purchase price is not an issue during partition. Otherwise, the premise of a JTWROS deed would be invalid and its purpose would be defeated. On the other hand, when a TIC property is partitioned, courts may be at liberty to consider unequal contributions to purchase price and adjust the tenants' distributions accordingly. In either partition situation, tenants may request credits for unequal contributions to expenses incurred ''after'' taking deed to the property. Such credits may cover utility and maintenance expenses, and are allocated according to shares. Credits for improvements to the property may be granted if the improvements actually increased the value of the property. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Partition (Law)}} [[Category:Real property law]] [[Category:Eminent domain]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox War Faction |name=Promised Day Brigade |war=the [[Iraq War]] |image=[[File:Flag of Promised Day Brigades.svg|border|200px]] |caption=Flag of the Promised Day Brigade. The text is لبيك يا محمد (''Labīk yā Muḥammad''), "Here we are, [[Muhammad]]!" |active=November 2008 – June 2014 |leaders=[[Muqtada al-Sadr]] |clans= |headquarters=[[Sadr City]], [[Baghdad]] |area= [[Iraq]] and [[Syria]] |strength=15,000 (2008){{cite web|url=http://www.stanford.edu/group/mappingmilitants/cgi-bin/groups/view/57?highlight=Mahdi+Army|title=Mahdi Army|author=Daniel Cassman|publisher=|accessdate=November 7, 2014}} 5,000 (2011){{cite web|url=http://www.iran-times.com/english/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2178:us-officials-name-3-iraqi-militias-armed-by-iran-to-kill-yanks&catid=98:whats-left&Itemid=425|title=US officials name 3 Iraqi militias armed by Iran to kill Yanks|publisher=|accessdate=November 7, 2014}} |partof={{flagicon image|Shiism arabic blue.svg}} [[Special Groups (Iraq)|Special Groups]] |previous=[[Mahdi Army]] |next=[[Peace Companies]] |allies={{flag|Syria}}
{{flag|Iran}}
{{flagicon image|Asa'ib Ahl Al-Haq flag.png}} [[Asa'ib Ahl al-Haq]]
{{flagicon image|Kata'ib Hezbollah flag.svg}} [[Kata'ib Hezbollah]]
{{flagicon image|Shiism arabic blue.svg}} [[Special Groups (Iraq)|Other Special Groups]] |opponents={{flagicon image|Flag of United States Forces – Iraq.png}} [[United States Forces – Iraq|United States-Iraq]]
{{flagicon image|Flag of Multi-National Force – Iraq.png|size=23px}} [[Multi-National Force – Iraq|MNF–I]]
{{flagicon|Syria|1932}} [[Free Syrian Army]]
{{flagicon|Islamic State}} [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] |battles=[[Iraq War]]
[[Syrian Civil War]] | designated_as_terror_group_by = {{UAE}}https://web.archive.org/web/20141117230142/http://www.wam.ae/ar/news/emirates-arab-international/1395272465559.html }} The '''Promised Day Brigade''' ([[Abbreviation|abbreviated]] '''PDB'''; [[Arabic language|Arabic]]: لواء اليوم الموعود ''Liwā‘ al-Yūm al-Maw‘ūd''), originally called the '''Muqawimun''' (Arabic: المقاومون ''al-Muqāwimūn''; "Resisters")[http://www.ndia.org/Divisions/Divisions/SOLIC/Documents/Command_Report_12-10-10.pdf Page 29] was a [[Shi'a]] organization and was an [[Iraqi insurgency (2003–11)|insurgent group]] operating in Iraq during the war. In 2010, it was one of the largest and most powerful of what the US military call [[Special Groups (Iraq)|"Special Groups"]] in Iraq. {{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/07/17/AR2009071703634_2.html | work=The Washington Post | title=U.S. Commanders Are Concerned About New Iraqi Restrictions on American Troops | first1=Ernesto | last1=Londoño | first2=Karen | last2=DeYoung | date=July 18, 2009 | accessdate=May 22, 2010}} The group was created as successor to [[Muqtada al-Sadr]]'s [[Mahdi Army]], which was Iraq's largest Shi'a militia until its disbanding in 2008, he also called on other Special Groups to join the brigade. Sadr had earlier already talked about the creation of a smaller guerrilla unit which would continue the Mahdi Army's armed activities but for the first time gave the organisation a name in November 2008 when he declared the creation of the Promised Day Brigade.{{Cite web |url=http://www.zimbio.com/War+in+Iraq/articles/3427/Iraq+Promised+Day+Brigade+reforming+Shiite# |title=Archived copy |access-date=February 7, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119123906/http://www.zimbio.com/War+in+Iraq/articles/3427/Iraq+Promised+Day+Brigade+reforming+Shiite# |archive-date=January 19, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} Its activities have particularly increased since May 2009. The group's name is in reference to an alternate term for the Islamic [[Islamic eschatology|Day of Judgment]].http://hadithaday.org/horrors-of-the-promised-day/horrors-of-the-promised-day/ The group is alleged{{by whom|date=October 2013}} to receive Iranian support. A crackdown against the group, in the end 2009, led to the arrest of 18 of its members including several commanders. http://www.defenddemocracy.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11787517&Itemid=361{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} On November 29, 2009, the group's [[Basra]] leader was arrested in [[Amarah|al-Amarah]].{{cite web|url=http://en.aswataliraq.info/?p=122748|title=Suspected armed group leader arrested in Missan|publisher=|accessdate=November 7, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303165447/http://en.aswataliraq.info/?p=122748#|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} In October 2009, the Promised Day Brigade fought a battle with rival Special Group [[Asa'ib Ahl al-Haq]] for influence in [[Sadr City]]. The Promised Day Brigade reportedly won the battle and even managed to destroy the house of Abdul [[Hadi al-Darraji]], a senior Asa'ib Ahl al-Haq leader. Since then, the PDB has been the most powerful Special Group in the ex-Mahdi Army stronghold of Sadr City and has increased its activity there.{{cite web|url=http://www.opendemocracy.net/opensecurity/shatha-al-juburi/can-iraqs-sadrists-prove-their-nationalist-credentials|title=Can Iraq's Sadrists prove their nationalist credentials?|work=openDemocracy|accessdate=November 7, 2014}} On July 21, 2010, General [[Raymond T. Odierno|Ray Odierno]] said Iran supports three Shiite groups in Iraq that had attempted to attack US bases: https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jCA6iGhsEI3i-z4hAG8Z2Cu4kV3Q US officials believe that of these three groups, the Promised Day Brigades poses the greatest threat to Iraq's long-term security. # the Promised Day Brigades # [[Kata'ib Hezbollah|Ketaib Hezbollah]] (Hezbollah Brigades) # [[Asa'ib Ahl al-Haq|Asaib Ahl al-Haq]] (League of the Righteous) ==See also== * [[List of armed groups in the Syrian Civil War]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Armed Iraqi Groups in the Iraq War and the Iraq Civil War}} {{Militant Islamism}} [[Category:Arab militant groups]] [[Category:Anti-ISIL factions in Iraq]] [[Category:Anti-ISIL factions in Syria]] [[Category:Factions in the Iraq War]] [[Category:Iraqi insurgency (2003–2011)]] [[Category:Paramilitary forces of Iraq]] [[Category:Pro-government factions of the Syrian Civil War]] [[Category:Rebel groups in Iraq]] [[Category:Resistance movements]] [[Category:Shia organizations]] [[Category:Sadr City]] [[Category:Organizations designated as terrorist by the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Organizations designated as terrorist in Asia]] [[Category:Jihadist groups in Iraq]]

In [[health policy]], '''Roemer's Law''' may be expressed as follows: "in an insured population, a hospital bed built is a filled bed".<ref>{{cite web|title=Obituary: Milton I. Roemer, Pioneering UCLA Health Services Professor and Professional Who Defined Health Policy in U.S., Abroad|url=http://www.ph.ucla.edu/pr/miroemer.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304021055/http://www.ph.ucla.edu/pr/miroemer.html|archivedate=4 March 2012|date=8 January 2001|website=University of California, Los Angeles School of Public Health}}</ref>
This rule was deduced by the American health services researcher Milton Roemer, working at the [[UCLA School of Public Health]]. Roemer and colleagues found a [[positive correlation]] between the number of short-term [[Hospital#General|general hospital]] beds available per 1,000 population and the number of hospital days used per 1,000 population.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Shain|first1=M|last2=Roemer|first2=MI|title=Hospital costs relate to the supply of beds|journal=Modern Hospital|date=April 1959|volume=92|issue=4|pages=71-3|pmid=13644010}}</ref>
Whilst clearly Roemer's Law will not always hold true (not every bed that is ever built will be filled), it does provide the underpinning for [[certificate of need]] laws and for health planning.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Problems and Prospects for Health Planning: The Importance of Incentives, Standards, and Procedures in Certificate of Need|url=http://mckinneylaw.iu.edu/instructors/orentlicher/healthlw/Chap10A2.html|first= Randall|last=Bovbjerg|journal=Utah Law Review|volume=83|date=1978}}</ref>{{Page needed|date=March 2015}}
The law is thought to be a consequence of [[induced demand]] i.e. physicians encouraging patients to consume services that the patients would not have chosen had they been fully informed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Roemer's Law of Demand|url=http://opus1journal.org/others/killerapps/Roemer_law.html|website=Opus1 Journal: The Journal of Undergraduate Research|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107032619/http://opus1journal.org/others/killerapps/Roemer_law.html|archivedate=7 January 2009|date=7 September 2005}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=Opus1 website appears amateurish, doesn't list author(s).|date=March 2015}} Health planning and [[certificate of need]] laws aim to prevent the waste that would otherwise occur due to Roemer's Law.
"One problem in this finding is that it could be the case that hospital stays are shorter in lower hospital bed [[per capita]] regions because of a deficit in [[supply (economics)|supply]] ([[reverse causation]]). An increased number of beds may be due to patient preference for [[in-patient]] (rather than [[outpatient]]) care in a region."<ref>{{cite web|title=Roemer's law|website=Healthcare Economist|date=12 October 2006|url=http://healthcare-economist.com/2006/10/12/roemers-law/|first=Jason|last=Shafrin}}{{Self-published source|date=March 2015}}</ref>{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=March 2015}}
[[Enoch Powell]] who was Minister of Health in the United Kingdom propounded a similar proposition, which he called Parkinson's Law of hospital beds: "the number of patients always tends to equality with the number of beds available for them to lie in."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Powell|first1=Enoch|title=A new look at Medicine and Politics|date=1966|url=http://www.sochealth.co.uk/national-health-service/healthcare-generally/history-of-healthcare/a-new-look-at-medicine-and-politics/a-new-look-at-medicine-and-politics-4/|accessdate=1 July 2015}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Roemer's law}} [[Category:Health economics]] [[Category:Health policy]]

page.title: Rome Declaration on World Food Security

revision.text:
{{Infobox Treaty | name = Rome Declaration on World Food Security | long_name = | image = | image_width = | caption = | type = | date_drafted = | date_signed = 13 November 1996 | location_signed = [[Rome]] | date_sealed = | date_effective = | condition_effective = | date_expiration = | signatories = | parties = | depositor = | language = | languages = | website = | wikisource = Rome Declaration on World Food Security }} The '''Rome Declaration on World Food Security''' is a document adopted at the 1996 [[World Food Summit]] took place in Rome, Italy between 13 and 17 November 1996. The summit was organised by the [[Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations]] (FAO). The '''Declaration''' reaffirms the right of everyone to have access to safe and nutritious food consistent with the right to adequate food and the fundamental right of everyone to be free from hunger and pledges political will and common and national commitment to achieving food security for all and to an ongoing effort to eradicate hunger in all countries with an immediate view to reducing the number of undernourished people to half their present level no later than 2015. Therefore, the document has important significance in relation to [[Food security]] and the [[Right to food]]. Signatories commit to the implementation of the [[World Food Summit Plan of Action]]. ==Right to food== In the Declaration, member states stated the following in relation to the right to food:
"We pledge our political will and our common and national commitment to achieving food security for all and to an ongoing effort to eradicate hunger in all countries, with an immediate view to reducing the number of undernourished people to half their present level no later than 2015."{{Cite web | title = Rome Declaration on World Food Security | authorlink = Rome Declaration on World Food Security | date = 13 November 1996 | url = http://www.fao.org/docrep/003/w3613e/w3613e00.htm | publisher = Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations | location = Rome | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/68CmJzQ0l | archivedate = 6 June 2012 |deadurl=no |accessdate=15 July 2013}}
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.fao.org/docrep/003/w3613e/w3613e00.htm Text of the Rome Declaration and Plan of Action(1996)] [[Category:Food security]]

[[File:A T Ariyarathna.jpg|thumb|Dr. A. T. Ariyaratne, the founder of Sarvodaya Shramadana Movement]] The '''Sarvodaya Shramadana Movement''' is a [[self-governance]] movement in [[Sri Lanka]], which provides comprehensive development and [[conflict resolution]] programs to villages. It is also the largest indigenous organization working in reconstruction from the [[tsunami]] caused by the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]]. Founded in 1958 by [[A. T. Ariyaratne]] when he took “forty high school students and twelve teachers from [[Nalanda College Colombo]] on “an educational experiment” to an outcaste village, Kathaluwa, and helped the villagers fix it up. It is based on [[Buddhist]] and [[Gandhism|Gandhian]] principles, including [[sarvodaya]] from which it got the name and [[swaraj]] (self-governance). The word "[[shramadana]]" means "a gift of labor".<ref name="Garfinkel">Perry Garfinkel, ''Buddha or bust'' (2006), p. 110</ref>
As of 2006, Sarvodaya staff people and programs are active in some 15,000 (of 38,000) villages in Sri Lanka. The organization estimates that 11 million citizens are individual beneficiaries of one of their programs. The group distributes funds from a financial reserve bank of 1.6 billion [[Sri Lankan rupee|rupees]].<ref name="Garfinkel"/>
== Program == The Sarvodaya program begins with an invitation from a village for discussion of what is needed and how it can be done. It proceeds in stages through creating a village council, building a school and clinic, setting up family programs, creating economic opportunity so that the village economy becomes self-sustaining, starting a village bank, and offering help to other villages. In addition, Sarvodaya sponsors public meditations in which tens and sometimes hundreds of thousands of Buddhists, Hindus, Muslims and Christians meditate together on each other's welfare, using the Buddhist [[Brahmavihara]] (sublime attitude) meditations, which are acceptable within all faiths.
[[Fusion – Sarvodaya ICT4D Movement]] is the ICT for development (ICT4D) program. As a response to the emerging digital divide issues of rural Sri Lanka, Sarvodaya started setting up telecentres experimentally in 1997. This has led to the pioneering [[telecentre]] program in the country. Village Information Centres (popularly known as VICs) are rural libraries, set up by village youth leaders as 'Zero Cost' village initiatives, which prepare disadvantaged, less educated rural communities for the information age. Out of the 172 VICs initiated since early 2000, there are about 21 VICs graduated to their own forms of telecentres by mid-2008.
Author John P. Clark has argued that the Sarvodaya Shramadana Movement are [[Anarchism|anarchist]] in their organisation and goals, noting their inspiration from the philosophical anarchist [[Mahatma Gandhi]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Impossible Community: Realising Communitarian Anarchism|last=Clark|first=John|publisher=|year=2013|isbn=9781441185471|location=|pages=}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Buddhism in Sri Lanka]] *[[Nonviolence]] *[[Shanthi Sena]]
== Notes and references== {{Reflist}} * Ariyaratne, A. T. (1986). Asian values as a basis for Asian development. In D. C. Korten (Ed.), ''Community management: Asian experience and perspectives'' (pp. 32–39). West Hartford, CT: Kumarian Press. * Ariyaratne, A. T. (1987). Beyond development communication: Case study on ''Sarvodaya'', Sri Lanka. In N. Jayaweera & S. Amunugama (Eds.), ''Rethinking development communication'' (pp. 239–251). Singapore: Asian Mass Communication Research and Information Center. * Bond, G. D. (2004). ''Buddhism at work: Community development, social empowerment and the Sarvodaya movement''. Bloomfield, CT: Kumarian Press. * Dissanayake, W. (2014). Development and communication in Sri Lanka: A Buddhist approach. In M. K. Asante, Y. Miike, & J. Yin (Eds.), ''The global intercultural communication reader'' (2nd ed., pp. 467–479). New York, NY: Routledge. * Macy, J. (1985). ''Dharma and development: Religion as resource in the Sarvodaya self-help movement'' (Rev. ed.). West Hartford, CT: Kumarian Press.
== External links == * http://www.sarvodaya.org * http://www.sarvodayausa.org * http://www.sarvodayanepal.org * http://www.sarvodaya.nl * http://www.fusion.lk * https://web.archive.org/web/20160303183259/http://sarvodayajapan.jimdo.com/ {{Commons category|Sarvodaya}}
[[Category:Youth organisations based in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Charities based in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Self-governance]]

Assembly of South Africa|House of Assembly]] | majority_seats = | opinion_polls = | turnout = <!-- person 1 --> | image1 = [[File:HF Verwoerd Transvaler.jpg|x130px]] | colour1 = | leader1 = [[Hendrik Verwoerd]] | party1 = National Party (South Africa) | leader_since1 = | leaders_seat1 = | last_election1 = 105 seats | seats_before1 = | seats_needed1 = | seats1 = 126 | seats_after1 = | seat_change1 = {{increase}}21 <!-- any --> | popular_vote1 = 759,331 | percentage1 = 58.31% | swing1 = {{increase}}12.20% <!-- person 2 --> | image2 = [[File:Sir De Villiers Graaff.jpg|x130px]] | colour2 = | leader2 = [[De Villiers Graaff]] | party2 = United Party (South Africa) | alliance2 = <!-- legislative or parliamentary --> | leader_since2 = | leaders_seat2 = | last_election2 = 49 seats | seats_before2 = | seats_needed2 = | seats2 = 39 | seats_after2 = | seat_change2 = {{decrease}}10 <!-- any --> | popular_vote2 = 486,629 | percentage2 = 37.37% | swing2 = {{increase}}1.49% <!-- bottom --> | title = Prime Minister | before_election = [[Hendrik Verwoerd]] | before_party = National Party (South Africa) | posttitle = | after_election = [[Hendrik Verwoerd]] | after_party = National Party (South Africa) | map_image = South African House of Assembly 1966.svg | map_size = 300px | map_caption = House of Assembly after the election }} {{Politics of South Africa}} The '''1966 South African general election''', on 30 March 1966, resulted in another comprehensive victory for the [[National Party (South Africa)|National Party]] under [[Hendrik Frensch Verwoerd]].
The election marked a major strengthening of power for the ruling NP, which gained a two thirds majority in parliament for the first time. The main opposition United Party slightly increased its share of the popular vote, but nevertheless saw its parliamentary representation considerably reduced.
The number of [[House of Assembly of South Africa|House of Assembly]] seats for White voters in South Africa had been increased from 150 to 160 by the Constitution Amendment Act of 1965. In addition, there were six seats for White voters from [[South-West Africa]] (now [[Namibia]]). There were also four seats reserved for [[Coloured]] representatives, who did not have to stand for re-election during 1966.
==Coloured Representative Members== The second election for the four coloured representative members had taken place on 4 October 1961, before the (white voters only) general election on 8 October 1961. Under the Separate Representation of Voters Act 1951, the members had been elected to serve until the dissolution of the 1961–1966 Parliament.
The Progressive Party (PP) won the two seats representing coloured voters on the [[Cape Provincial Council]], at an election in 1965. The National Party (NP) government became concerned at the prospect of four additional Progressive MPs being elected. The opposition United Party (UP) also feared the loss of support, if the existing four UP supported independent members were defeated.
Parliament passed the Separate Representation of Voters Amendment Act 1965. This legislation extended the term of the existing coloured representatives until October 1966.<ref>''Keesing's Contemporary Archives, 1965–1966'', pages 21375-21376</ref> Further Separate Representation of Voters Amendment Acts, in 1966 and 1968, extended the term until the dissolution of what turned out to be the 1966–1970 Parliament. The coloured representation in Parliament would then be abolished.<ref>''In No Uncertain Terms'', pp 84</ref>
==Delimitation of electoral divisions== The [[South Africa Act 1909]] had provided for a delimitation commission to define the boundaries for each electoral division, for general roll voters in the four provinces. The republican constitution continued the arrangements for a commission. The representation by province, under the twelfth delimitation report of 1965, is set out in the table below. The figures in brackets are the number of electoral divisions in the previous (1958) delimitation. If there is no figure in brackets then the number was unchanged.<ref>''South Africa 1982'', page 129 (table setting out delimitations of seats by province, the relevant one being that of 1965)</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Provinces !! Cape !! Natal !! Orange Free State !! Transvaal !! Total |- | Divisions ||align="center" | 54 (52) || align="center" | 18 (16) || align="center" | 15 (14) || align="center" | 73 (68) || align="center" | '''160 (150)''' |}
South-West Africa (with six seats) and the coloured representatives (4 seats), were unaffected by the general delimitation provisions.
==Composition at the dissolution== The 13th Parliament since the Union of 1910 and the 1st elected after the republic was proclaimed in 1961, was dissolved in 1966. At the time the House of Assembly consisted of two groups of members. White voters were represented by 156 general roll members and coloured voters in Cape Province by four white MPs known at the time as Coloured Representative Members (CRM).
The general election only affected the representatives of white voters. The other members were elected on a different date (see above).
Since the previous election, the United Party had absorbed the National Union, with which it had had an electoral alliance in 1961.
The representation by party and province, at the dissolution was:- <ref>''Keesing's Contemporary Archives, 1965–1966'', pages 21375-21376</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Province !! National !! United !! Progressive !! Independents !! Total |- | Cape (general) ||align="center" | 34 ||align="center" | 18 ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | 52 |- | Cape (CRM) ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | 4 ||align="center" | 4 |- | Natal ||align="center" | 3 ||align="center" | 13 ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | 16 |- | Orange Free State ||align="center" | 14 ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | 14 |- | South-West Africa ||align="center" | 6 ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | 6 |- | Transvaal ||align="center" | 49 ||align="center" | 18 ||align="center" | 1 ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | 68 |- | '''Total''' ||align="center" | '''106''' ||align="center" | '''49''' ||align="center" | '''1''' ||align="center" | '''4''' ||align="center" | '''160''' |}
==Election results== The vote totals in the table below may not give a complete picture of the balance of political opinion, because of unopposed elections (where no votes were cast) and because contested seats may not have been fought by a candidate from all major parties. In all, eighteen candidates were returned unopposed, seventeen representing the National Party and one the United Party. The Progressive Party barely kept its [[Houghton, Johannesburg|Houghton]] seat, held by [[Helen Suzman]] since her defection from the UP, with a bare 117 votes.<ref>http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,835282,00.html</ref>
356 candidates were nominated. These represented the following parties: National 154, United 141, Progressive 26, Republican 22, the Front 10, Independents 2, and Conservative National Party 1. The Republican, Front and Conservative National groups were new right-wing parties, which had not contested previous general elections.
The total registered electorate was 1,901,479. The votes cast were 1,302,151 (including 7,494 spoilt votes).<ref>''South Africa 1982'', page 176</ref>
{| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%" |- | colspan=2 align="center" | '''Party''' | align="center" | '''Seats'''<ref>''South Africa 1982'', page 174 (seats by party)</ref> | align="center" | '''Seats %''' | align="center" | '''Votes'''<ref>''South Africa 1982'', page 176 (votes by party)</ref> | align="center" | '''Votes %''' | align="center" | '''Leader''' |- {{Party name with colour|National Party (South Africa)}} | align="center" | 126 | align="center" | 75.90 | align="center" | 759,331 | align="center" | 58.31 | align="right" | [[Hendrik Verwoerd]] |- {{Party name with colour|United Party (South Africa)}} | align="center" | 39 | align="center" | 23.49 | align="center" | 486,629 | align="center" | 37.37 | align="right" | [[De Villiers Graaff|Sir de Villiers Graaff]] |- {{Party name with colour|Progressive Party (South Africa)}} | align="center" | [[Helen Suzman|1]] | align="center" | 0.60 | align="center" | 39,717 | align="center" | 3.05 | align="right" | [[Jan Steytler]] |- {{Party name with colour|Independent (politics)}} | align="center" | – | align="center" | – | align="center" | 16,474 | align="center" | 1.27 | align="center" | – |- | | '''Total''' | align="center" | '''166''' |}
The overall composition of the House, after the general election, by province and party is set out in the table below.

Total |- | Cape (general) ||align="center" | 38 ||align="center" | 16 ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | 54 |- | Cape (CRM) ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | 4 ||align="center" | 4 |- | Natal ||align="center" | 5 ||align="center" | 13 ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | 18 |- | Orange Free State ||align="center" | 15 ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | 15 |- | South-West Africa ||align="center" | 6 ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | 6 |- | Transvaal ||align="center" | 62 ||align="center" | 10 ||align="center" | 1 ||align="center" | – ||align="center" | 73 |- | '''Total''' ||align="center" | '''126''' ||align="center" | '''39''' ||align="center" | '''1''' ||align="center" | '''4''' ||align="center" | '''170''' |}

{{Infobox political party |name = Tamil United Liberation Front |native_name = தமிழர் ஐக்கிய விடுதலை முன்னணி
ද්‍රවිඩ එක්සත් විමුක්ති පෙරමුණ |logo = |colorcode = Yellow |leader = [[V. Anandasangaree]] |chairperson = |president = |secretary_general = |founder = [[S. J. V. Chelvanayakam]],
[[G. G. Ponnambalam]],
[[Savumiamoorthy Thondaman]] |leader1_title = Secretary |leader1_name = K. K. Kanagarajah |slogan = |founded = {{start date and age|df=yes|p=y|1972|05|04}} |dissolved = |merger = [[All Ceylon Tamil Congress]], [[Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi]], [[Ceylon Workers' Congress]] |split = |predecessor = [[Tamil United Front]] |merged = |successor = |headquarters = 5/3A Wijayaba Mawatha, Kalubowila, [[Dehiwala]] |newspaper = |student_wing = |youth_wing = |membership_year = |membership = |ideology = [[Sri Lankan Tamil Nationalism|Tamil Nationalism]] |religion = |national = |international = |european = |europarl = |affiliation1_title = |affiliation1 = |colors = |seats1_title = |seats1 = |seats2_title = |seats2 = |seats3_title = |seats3 = |symbol = Rising Sun
[[Image:TULFS.png|100px|TULF Election Symbol]] |flag = |website = |country = Sri Lanka |footnotes = }} The '''Tamil United Liberation Front''' ({{lang-ta|தமிழர் ஐக்கிய விடுதலை முன்னணி}}, {{lang-si|ද්‍රවිඩ එක්සත් විමුක්ති පෙරමුණ}}) is a [[political party]] in [[Sri Lanka]] which seeks independence for the [[Sri Lankan Tamils|Tamil]]-populated areas of Sri Lanka. ==Formation== On May 4, 1972 several Tamil political groups, including the [[All Ceylon Tamil Congress]], formed the Tamil United Front (TUF). The [[Federal Party (Sri Lanka)|Federal Party]] joined the TUF in 1976. The TUF changed its name to the Tamil United Liberation Front (TULF) and adopted a demand for an independent state to be known as the "secular, socialist state of [[Tamil Eelam]]". ==1977 Parliamentary General Election== In the first general election contested by the TULF, the [[Sri Lankan parliamentary election, 1977|21 July 1977 election]] in which the [[United National Party|UNP]] won by a landslide, the TULF won 6.40% of the popular vote and 18 out of 168 seats in the [[Sri Lankan parliament]], including all 14 seats in the [[Northern Province, Sri Lanka|Northern Province]]. '''Votes and seats won by TULF by electoral district''' {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Electoral District ! align=right|Votes ! align=right|% ! align=right|Seats ! align=right|Turnout ! TULF MP |- | [[Batticaloa Electoral District (1947-1989)|Batticaloa]] | align=right|26,648 | align=right|24.70% | align=right|1 | align=right|71.15% | Chelliah Rajadurai |- | [[Chavakacheri Electoral District|Chavakachcheri]] | align=right|20,028 | align=right|63.27% | align=right|1 | align=right|85.65% | [[V. N. Navaratnam]] |- | [[Jaffna Electoral District (1947-1989)|Jaffna]] | align=right|16,251 | align=right|56.62% | align=right|1 | align=right|82.32% | [[V. Yogeswaran]] |- | [[Kalkudah Electoral District|Kalkudah]] | align=right|12,595 | align=right|43.07% | align=right|0 | align=right|86.02% | |- | [[Kalmunai Electoral District|Kalmunai]] | align=right|7,093 | align=right|27.38% | align=right|0 | align=right|89.86% | |- | [[Kankesanthurai Electoral District|Kankesanthurai]] | align=right|31,155 | align=right|85.41% | align=right|1 | align=right|83.08% | [[A. Amirthalingam]] |- | [[Kayts Electoral District|Kayts]] | align=right|17,640 | align=right|64.05% | align=right|1 | align=right|75.72% | [[K. P. Soosaithasan |- | [[Mullaitivu Electoral District|Mullaitivu]] | align=right|10,261 | align=right|52.36% | align=right|1 | align=right|79.34% | X. M. Sellathambu |- | [[Mutur Electoral District|Mutur]] | align=right|7,520 | align=right|27.00% | align=right|0 | align=right|91.65% | |- | [[Nallur Electoral District|Nallur]] | align=right|29,858 | align=right|89.42% | align=right|1 | align=right|83.05% | [[M. Sivasithamparam]] |- | [[Paddiruppu Electoral District|Paddirippu]] | align=right|15,877 | align=right|49.17% | align=right|1 | align=right|89.92% | P. Ganeshalingam |- | [[Point Pedro Electoral District|Point Pedro]] | align=right|12,989 | align=right|55.91% | align=right|1 | align=right|81.66% | [[K. Thurairatnam]] |- | [[Pottuvil Electoral District|Pottuvil]] | align=right|23,990 | align=right|26.97% | align=right|1 | align=right|179.02% | M. Kanagaratnam |- | Puttalam | align=right|3,268 | align=right|10.52% | align=right|0 | align=right|83.58% | |- | [[Sammanthurai Electoral District|Sammanthurai]] | align=right|8,615 | align=right|34.65% | align=right|0 | align=right|91.04% | |- | [[Trincomalee Electoral District (1947-1989)|Trincomalee]] | align=right|15,144 | align=right|51.76% | align=right|1 | align=right|81.78% | [[R. Sampanthan]] |- | [[Udupiddy Electoral District|Udupiddy]] | align=right|18,768 | align=right|63.44% | align=right|1 | align=right|80.05% | T. Rasalingam |- | [[Vaddukoddai Electoral District|Vaddukoddai]] | align=right|23,384 | align=right|70.18% | align=right|1 | align=right|81.90% | T. Thirunavukarasu |- | [[Vavuniya Electoral District|Vavuniya]] | align=right|13,821 | align=right|59.02% | align=right|1 | align=right|82.31% | [[T. Sivasithamparam]] |- | '''Total''' | align=right|'''399,043''' | align=right|'''6.40%''' | align=right|'''18''' | | |- |align=left colspan=6|Source:{{cite web|url=http://www.slelections.gov.lk/web/images/pdf/general-election-results/general-election-1977.pdf|title=Result of Parliamentary General Election 1977|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Department of Elections, Sri Lanka|access-date=}} |} The TULF became the official opposition as result of the rout of the [[Sri Lanka Freedom Party|SLFP]]. The TULF's success would lead to [[Sri Lankan riots of 1977|riots]] in which hundreds of [[Tamils]] were murdered by [[Sinhala people|Sinhala]] mobs. Throughout the 1970s and early 1980s, the TULF was frequently blamed by nationalist [[Sinhalese people|Sinhalese]] politicians for acts of violence committed by [[List of Tamil militant groups|militant groups]] such as the [[Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam]] (LTTE). In fact, the TULF represented an older, more conservative generation of Tamils that felt independence could be achieved without violence, more rival than ally to youth groups like the LTTE who believed in armed conflict. In October 1983, all the TULF legislators, numbering sixteen at the time, forfeited their seats in Parliament for refusing to swear an oath unconditionally renouncing support for a separate state in accordance with the Sixth Amendment to the Constitution of Sri Lanka. During the 1980s, the LTTE began to see the TULF as a rival in its desire to be considered the sole representatives of the Tamils of the north and east. Over the next two decades, the LTTE has assassinated several TULF leaders, including [[A. Amirthalingam]] and [[Neelan Thiruchelvam]]. ==1989 Parliamentary General Election== The TULF formed an alliance with the three [[India]]n backed [[paramilitary]] groups, [[Eelam National Democratic Liberation Front]] (ENDLF), [[Eelam People's Revolutionary Liberation Front]] (EPRLF) and [[Tamil Eelam Liberation Organization]] (TELO), to contest the [[Sri Lankan parliamentary election, 1989|15 February 1989 election]]. The alliance won 3.40% of the popular vote and 10 out of 225 seats in the [[Sri Lankan parliament]]. '''Votes and seats won by TULF / ENDLF / EPRLF / TULF alliance by electoral district''' {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! [[Electoral districts in Sri Lanka|Electoral
District]] ! align=right|Votes ! align=right|% ! align=right|Seats ! align=right|Turnout ! Amirthalingam]]) |- | '''Total''' | align=right|'''188,593''' | align=right|'''3.40%''' | align=right|'''10''' | align=right|'''63.6%''' | |- |align=left colspan=6|Sources: {{cite web |title=Result of Parliamentary General Election 1989 |url=http://www.slelections.gov.lk/pdf/Results_1989%20GENERAL%20ELECTION.PDF |publisher=Department of Elections, Sri Lanka |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20090304101343/http://www.slelections.gov.lk/pdf/Results_1989%20GENERAL%20ELECTION.PDF |archivedate=2009-03-04 |df= }}{{cite web |author=D. B. S. Jeyaraj |title=The benign parliamentarian from Batticaloa |url=http://transcurrents.com/tamiliana/index.php/archives/category/transcurrents/page/24/ |date=1 January 2006 |publisher=TransCurrents |authorlink=David Jeyaraj |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091110120635/http://transcurrents.com/tamiliana/index.php/archives/category/transcurrents/page/24 |archivedate=10 November 2009 |df= }} |} ==1994 Parliamentary General Election== In the [[Sri Lankan parliamentary election, 1994|16 August 1994 election]] in which the [[People's Alliance (Sri Lanka)|People's Alliance]] led by [[Chandrika Kumaratunga]] came to power after 17 years of [[United National Party|UNP]] rule, the TULF won 1.60% of the popular vote and 5 out of 225 seats in the [[Sri Lankan parliament]]. District]] ! align=right|Votes ! align=right|% ! align=right|Seats ! align=right|Turnout ! Thangathurai]] |- | National List | | | align=right|1 | | [[Neelan Tiruchelvam|Dr. Neelan Tiruchelvam]], murdered 29 July 1999
[[Mavai Senathirajah]], from August 1999 (replaces [[Neelan Tiruchelvam|Dr. Neelan Tiruchelvam]]) |- | '''Total''' | align=right|'''132,461''' | align=right|'''1.60%''' | align=right|'''5''' | align=right|'''76.23%''' | |- |align=left colspan=6|Sources: {{cite web |title=Result of Parliamentary General Election 1994 |url=http://www.slelections.gov.lk/pdf/Results_1994%20GENERAL%20ELECTION-SM01.PDF |publisher=Department of Elections, Sri Lanka |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101006015411/http://www.slelections.gov.lk/pdf/Results_1994%20GENERAL%20ELECTION-SM01.PDF |archivedate=2010-10-06 |df= }}{{cite web |title=Senathirajah - new TULF MP |url=http://lakdiva.com/island/i990815/news.htm |date=15 August 1999 |publisher=The Island, Sri Lanka |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081001182433/http://lakdiva.com/island/i990815/news.htm |archivedate=1 October 2008 |df= }} |} ==2000 Parliamentary General Election== In the [[Sri Lankan parliamentary election, 2000|10 October 2000 election]] in which the [[People's Alliance (Sri Lanka)|People's Alliance]] led by [[Ratnasiri Wickremanayake]] retained to power, the TULF won 1.23% of the popular vote and 5 out of 225 seats in the [[Sri Lankan parliament]]. '''Votes and seats won by TULF by electoral district''' {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! [[Electoral districts in Sri Lanka|Electoral
District]] ! align=right|Votes ! align=right|% ! align=right|Seats ! align=right|Turnout ! TULF MPs |- | valign=top|[[Batticaloa Electoral District|Batticaloa]] | valign=top align=right|54,448 | valign=top align=right|29.20% | valign=top align=right|2 | valign=top align=right|71.74% | [[Joseph Pararajasingham]]
Nimalan Soundaranayagam |- | valign=top|[[Jaffna Electoral District|Jaffna]] | valign=top align=right|32,852 | valign=top align=right|27.59% | valign=top align=right|3 | valign=top align=right|21.32% | [[V. Anandasangaree]]
[[Mavai Senathirajah]]
[[S. Sivamaharajah]] |- | valign=top|[[Trincomalee Electoral District|Trincomalee]] | valign=top align=right|14,090 | valign=top align=right|10.58% | valign=top align=right|0 | valign=top align=right|68.52% | |- | valign=top|[[Vanni Electoral District|Vanni]] | valign=top align=right|4,643 | valign=top align=right|5.58% | valign=top align=right|0 | valign=top align=right|42.13% | |- | valign=top|National List | | | valign=top align=right|0 | | |- | '''Total''' | align=right|'''106,033''' | align=right|'''1.23%''' | align=right|'''5''' | align=right|'''75.62%''' |- |align=left colspan=6|Sources: {{cite web |title=Parliamentary General Election 10.10.2000, Final District Results |url=http://www.slelections.gov.lk/District2000/district2000.html |publisher=Department of Elections, Sri Lanka |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120805184625/http://www.slelections.gov.lk/District2000/district2000.html |archivedate=2012-08-05 |df= }}{{cite web |title=EPDP gets four seats in Jaffna |url=http://www.tamilnet.com/art.html?catid=13&artid=5487 |date=11 October 2000|publisher=[[TamilNet]]}}{{cite web |title=Pararajasingham elected on final count |url=http://www.tamilnet.com/art.html?catid=13&artid=5488 |date=11 October 2000|publisher=[[TamilNet]]}} |} ==2001 Parliamentary General Election== {{Tamil National Alliance 2010 parliamentary election results}} ==Split== TULF President [[V. Anandasangaree]], a critic of the [[Tamil Tigers]], left the [[Tamil National Alliance]] when it took a pro-Tamil Tigers stance at the [[Sri Lankan parliamentary election, 2004|2004 general election]]. Anandasangaree gained control of the TULF after a legal battle, forcing the TULF members who wanted to remain in the TNA to resurrect the [[Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi]], which is now a constituent party of the TNA. ==2004 Parliamentary General Election== The legal battle over the control of TULF meant that the TULF led by V. Anandasangaree contested as an [[Independent (politician)|independent group]] and only in one electoral district in the [[Sri Lankan parliamentary election, 2004|2 April 2004 parliamentary election]], winning 0.06% of the popular vote and no seats in the [[Sri Lankan parliament]]. '''Votes and seats won by TULF by electoral district''' {| class="wikitable" border="1" style="text-align:right;" |- ! [[Electoral districts in Sri Lanka|Electoral
District]] !! valign=bottom|Votes !! valign=bottom|% !! valign=bottom|Seats !! valign=bottom|Turnout !! valign=bottom|TULF MPs |- | align=left|[[Jaffna Electoral District|Jaffna]] || 5,156 || 1.82% || 0 || 47.38% || |- | align=left|'''Total''' || '''5,156''' || '''0.06%''' || '''0''' || '''75.96%''' || |- |align=left colspan=6|Source:{{cite web |title=Parliamentary General Election 2004, Final District Results |url=http://www.slelections.gov.lk/District2004/district2004.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107100926/http://www.slelections.gov.lk/District2004/district2004.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2009-01-07 |publisher=Department of Elections, Sri Lanka }} |} ==2010 Parliamentary General Election== In the [[Sri Lankan parliamentary election, 2010|8 April 2010 parliamentary election]] in which the [[United People's Freedom Alliance]] led by [[Mahinda Rajapaksa|President Rajapaksa]] retained power, the TULF led by V. Anandasangaree won 0.11% of the popular vote and no seats in the [[Sri Lankan parliament]]. '''Votes and seats won by TULF by electoral district''' {| class="wikitable" border="1" style="text-align:right;" |- ! [[Electoral districts in Sri Lanka|Electoral
District]] !! valign=bottom|Votes !! valign=bottom|% !! valign=bottom|Seats !! valign=bottom|Turnout !! valign=bottom|TULF MPs |- | align=left|[[Batticaloa Electoral District|Batticaloa]] || 4,424 || 2.45% || 0 || 58.56% || |- | align=left|[[Colombo Electoral District|Colombo]] || 834 || 0.09% || 0 || 65.03% || |- | align=left|[[Jaffna Electoral District|Jaffna]] || 2,892 || 1.95% || 0 || 23.33% || |- | align=left|[[Vanni Electoral District|Vanni]] || 1,073 || 1.00% || 0 || 43.89% || |- | align=left|'''Total''' || '''9,223''' || '''0.11%''' || '''0''' || '''61.26%''' || |- |align=left colspan=6|Source:{{cite web|title=Parliamentary General Election – 2010|url=http://www.slelections.gov.lk/parliamentary_elections/province.html|publisher=Department of Elections, Sri Lanka|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100414123543/http://www.slelections.gov.lk/parliamentary_elections/province.html|archivedate=2010-04-14|df=}} |} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.tulf.org/ Official '''Tamil United Liberation Front—TULF''' website] {{Sri Lankan political parties}} {{Sri Lankan Tamil people}} [[Category:Tamil United Liberation Front| ]] [[Category:Tamil political parties in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Political parties in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Tamil Eelam]] [[Category:Secessionist organizations in Asia]] [[Category:1972 establishments in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1972]]
